message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The descriptions of the patient's hearing loss suggest damage to the inner ear or specifically the organ of Corti, which is responsible for detection of sound. The Rinne test results indicate that sound is being transmitted through the air normally, ruling out perforation of the tympanic membrane or immobility of the stapes as a cause. A normal Weber test rules out unilateral hearing loss or differences in pressure, making excess endolymphatic fluid pressure less likely as a cause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient reports difficulty hearing high-pitched sounds but can easily hear low-pitched sounds. This suggests destruction of the organ of Corti, which is responsible for detecting high-frequency sounds. The Rinne test and Weber test both suggest normal conduction, ruling out perforation of the tympanic membrane and immobility of the stapes. Excess endolymphatic fluid pressure would cause symptoms of vertigo and tinnitus, which are not reported by the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of difficulty hearing high-pitched sounds, with normal Rinne and Weber tests, suggests damage to the organ of Corti, which is responsible for detecting high-frequency sounds. Perforation of the tympanic membrane or immobility of the stapes would result in conductive hearing loss, while excess endolymphatic fluid pressure would result in sensorineural hearing loss.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of difficulty hearing high-frequency sounds and normal Weber and Rinne tests suggest damage to the organ of Corti, which is responsible for detecting high-frequency sounds. Perforation of the tympanic membrane would affect transmission of sound waves to the middle ear, while immobility of the stapes would result in a conductive hearing loss. Excess endolymphatic fluid pressure is associated with Meniere's disease, which usually presents with vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest high-frequency hearing loss, which is commonly caused by damage to the organ of Corti in the cochlea. The normal results of the Rinne and Weber tests rule out perforation of the tympanic membrane and immobility of the stapes, which would show abnormal results. Excess endolymphatic fluid pressure would cause symptoms of vertigo and tinnitus, as seen in Meniere's disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms presented by the patient suggest sensorineural hearing loss, which can occur due to the destruction of the organ of Corti. The normal Rinne and Weber tests indicate that there are no issues with the structures of the middle ear or the auditory nerve, ruling out options A, B, and D.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a sensorineural hearing loss, and the Rinne test result confirms this. The Weber test not lateralizing suggests that the hearing loss is likely bilateral. Destruction of the organ of Corti in the inner ear can result in this type of hearing loss. Perforation of the tympanic membrane or immobility of the stapes would result in a conductive hearing loss, and excess endolymphatic fluid pressure would result in Meniere's disease, which typically includes vertigo and tinnitus in addition to hearing loss.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest sensorineural hearing loss, which can be caused by destruction of the organ of Corti. The Rinne test result indicates that the patient has normal conductive hearing, ruling out options (A) and (B). The Weber test result not lateralizing suggests that there is no significant asymmetry in his hearing, ruling out option (D).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and Rinne test results suggest that hearing loss is due to damage to the organ of Corti, which is responsible for transducing sound into electrical impulses that the brain can understand. Options A and B are related to conductive hearing loss, which would have a bone conduction greater than air conduction. Option D is related to Meniere's disease, which would also have other symptoms such as tinnitus and vertigo.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest sensorineural hearing loss, which is caused by damage to the inner ear or the auditory nerve. Since the Rinne test shows air conduction greater than bone conduction bilaterally, it is more likely that the damage occurred in the area of the organ of Corti, which is responsible for detecting sounds. Immobility of the stapes would result in conductive hearing loss instead. Perforation of the tympanic membrane and excess endolymphatic fluid pressure can also cause hearing loss but would not present with the specific pattern of difficulty hearing certain sounds while being able to hear others.
